title: The $30 3D scanner V7 updates
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Firstly, a big thank you to Thingiverse for featuring this design!
Secondly, since it has been featured i'm getting asked lots of questions, please bear with me, i will try and answer them as quickly as i can.. sorry in advance if i forget!

If you're looking for a 3D printer with a massive build volume, this one is incredible value for money
https://www.gearbest.com/3d-printers-3d-printer-kits/pp_701649.html?lkid=12386232
I have added some new parts to mine from here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2580773
This costs about $8 in extra parts but will take this printer from being a bit lame, to being easily one of the best large 3D printers out there. (better for more advanced users)

If you want a large build volume printer, with none of the hassle and 30min assembly time, The Anet E12 is incredible! From out of the box to first print within 1 hour. Full review coming soon.
https://www.gearbest.com/printers/pp_1072330.html?lkid=12666474
(This is great for everyone! Beginners to Advanced will all love this!)

If you're looking for a great value 3D printer and don't mind building it yourself, this one works great for me! (better for beginners)
http://www.gearbest.com/3d-printers-3d-printer-kits/pp_640022.html?wid=21&lkid=11019934

**This 3D printed design will turn your iPhone into a cheap portable 3D scanner utilising the AWESOME Autodesk Remake software

https://remake.autodesk.com**

Sadly Autodesk have decided to retire Remake and rebrand it as Recap Photo, which needs a premium subscription. This puts it way out of most peoples grasp.

Fear Not!
There is a free personal version of 3DF Zephyr available for you to play with.
The work flow is very similar to Remake.
https://www.3dflow.net/3df-zephyr-free/

The idea is that you use your phones onboard camera to take the pictures while the turn table rotates. This is acheived by using the headphones that were supplied new in the box

The volume controllers trigger the camera remotely, taking 55 pictures for every complete rotation of the turntable.

Full project tutorial available here

https://www.hackster.io/daveclarke/3d-scanner-turntable-for-cell-phones-64fdb8

Anyone wanting the Fusion360 CAD files, they can be downloaded here
http://a360.co/2eKZHq5

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/UGwlAmcAsJ4" ></iframe>
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zzcjlBCsNWY" ></iframe>
Assembly Exploded Video
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/vnhFHNdrJEY" ></iframe>
If you've ever wondered what my workflow is, check this out
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/GEAbXYDzUjU" ></iframe>
Brilliant Walkthrough tutorial for an Opensource Photogrammerty Workflow

How do i pay you $30 for this?

It's Free!

the $30 refers to an approximate PLA filament cost

What files do i need to use to print the scanner?

For the most part you will need
V2_chassis_cog_cover.stl
V2_cog.stl
V2_crank_handle_1.stl
V2_crank_handle_2.stl
V2_crank_wheel.stl
V2_iphone_cradle.stl (this is also OK for other phones it's just the name)
V4_Main_Chassis_1.stl (Updated 15/05/17 to allow lightening and USB C connectors to fit)
V2_Main_Chassis_2.stl
V3_Main_Chassis_3.stl
V2_Main_Chassis_4.stl
V2_Main_Chassis_combined.stl (V6 Update, use this is you have a printer big enough to print the base as 1 piece)
V2_stopper.stl (this is optional and is used to secure the headphone volume in place)
V2_Turn_Table.stl

Now if you find that V2_Turn_table.stl is too big for your build plate, you can download this as 3 seperate parts:
V3_Turn_Table_Split_1.stl
V3_Turn_Table_Split_2.stl
V3_Turn_Table_Split_3.stl

There is also a new version of the cog cover with a flange to help keep the turn table in place when using it with light objects. This will need to be glued in place

V4 chassis cog cover with Turn table support.stl
(This is now at V4 as of 08/06/17, it has been thickened to allow for a sturdy, support free print.)

From 02/11/17 The turntable has a 5 pcs split version so it can be printed on a 6" build plate
Use files
V3_Turn_Table_Split_1.stl
Turntable Split 5pcs 1.stl
Turntable Split 5pcs 3.stl
Turntable Split 5pcs 4.stl
Turntable Split 5pcs 2.stl

What App do you use?

I use Autodesk Remake. There is a free trial available. There are other photogrammetry software packages available, so it's worth having a look around. This is a PC app, not a mobile app

There are also Opensource options available, using VisualSFM, Meshlab and Blender. A brilliant tutorial has been done i have added the link in the video section below. It's excellent and a complete walkthrough. Amazing work!

Does this work with Android phone?

Yes, the turn table is designed to trigger your phones camera to take 50 pictures per full revolution. You use these photos with Autodesk Remake to create the 3D scan

The turntable is too big for my printer, can it be scaled down?

There have been some successful prints at 80% the original size, so yes but i recommend not going much smaller

Is there a version of the turntable part, split in two?

Yes, the wonderful Thingiverse community have added a few remixes, check them out on the remixes button
There is now a V3 turntable that has been split into 3 parts and should fit most printers

Does it need to print with supports?

The majority will print support free, but you will need supports for the main chassis. these are minimal however.

My iPhone 7 doesn't have a headphone jack, can i still use it?

Yes you can, just use the included headphones that came with it.

V7 Updates

The Turntable has a 5 pcs split version so it can be printed on a 6" build plate

V6 Update

You can now print the main chassis as 1 single piece. You'll need a printer with a large build volume, but it's another option for you

Update V5

V4 chassis cog cover with Turn table support.stl

This is now at V4 as of 08/06/17, it has been thickened to allow for a sturdy, support free print

Update V4

V4 Improvements

V4_Main_Chassis_1.stl Updated to allow lightening and USB C connectors to fit

Update V3

V3 improvements

  1. Turntable now split into 3 parts for easier printing, the unsplit part will remain for anyone who has a big enough printer volume
  2. Main Chassis split 1 and 3 are now V3. The ledges have been thickened up, and support material will now be easier to remove
    3.There is also a new version of the cog cover with a flange to help keep the turn table in place when using it with light objects. This will need to be glued in place
    V3 chassis cog cover with Turn table support.stl
Update V2

V2.0beta is now available for download!

The base is now in 4 separate parts that press fit together and the tolerancing on other press fit parts has been improved.

The iPhone Cradle is now also Height Adjustable to allow for further tweakablility and allow scanning of smaller items

(If you have already printed all the parts but just want to upgrade the main chassis, that will be no problem as the design is backward compatible)

Pinshape.com 's Functional Design 2016

I won the Top Functional Design in the 2016 Pinshape Awards! Thanks to all who voted! http://bit.ly/2j62lb0

The Formlabs Design Awards - Top Functional Model

In celebration of FUSE, Formlabs' first user conference, we are hosting the Formlabs 3D Design Awards, Powered by Pinshape.

The Formlabs Design Awards, powered by Pinshape, celebrated designs from the 3D printing community’s top contributors. Designs were nominated for one of three categories: Top Art and Design Model, Top Functional Model, and Top Educational Model. The results of public voting are in! Scroll on to learn about the winners for each category.

Top Functional Model
The Top Functional Model award goes to Daveyclk for his design, The $30 3D Scanner. This clever model can be entirely 3D printed. It works by using a smartphone to take a number of images and stitch them together via a process called photogrammetry. Congratulations and we hope the Solidworks and Instructables memberships help you to keep innovating!

https://formlabs.com/fuse17/3d-design-awards

comments.text:
everyone asking if it compatible with this and that.....its compatible with everything that has a camera!
Procedure:
-Place something with a camera on the camera stand
-place part on plate
-start filming
-rotate a few revolutions
-transfer video to PC
-convert video to images (30images*seconds=num of images)
-import images to opensource visualSFM program.....or any other structure from motion software
-you get point cloud
-now depends on the program, matlab can transform point cloud directly to .stl
-thats it

comments.author: rvncto

comments.text:
I print in PLA at 190. But I keep the bed at 50 (straight onto glass, no glue or tape). I do this so the first layer solidifies in a timely manner. If the first layer is in its glass state above 60, and then the subsequent layers on top cool and solidify with the fan, they contract in size. This contraction will pull up the bottom molten layer (warping). Use clean 3mm glass, or tape etc and keep bed temp 50 or less.
When the print finishes, the bed cools and contracts making the print pop off easily. And it has a nice smooth bottom!
Brims help with small surface area contact prints.
comments.author: rvncto

comments.text: Try hairspray or purple glue stick on the bed.
comments.author: rvncto

comments.text: If you're seeing the warping on the bed plate, can try using a brim. A raft can do it too but it's more filament

comments.text: Did my best to scan the comments for this question and didn't see it, please forgive me if I missed it.  Does the platform color affect the quality of the scanning?  Would a black, grey, or white work better than say a blue, red, or green?  Clearly film is shot against a green screen for special effects for removal.  Perhaps something contrasting to the item being scanned would be best, have you tested various colors?
comments.author: FineClonier

comments.text:
Hello, i found the colour of the platform does not matter very much, but the colour of the background you're scanning against works best as white. If you can avoid shadows being cast as well, this will lead to a more successful scan
Hope this helps

comments.text: The original V2 front parts have been replaced, mainly to reduce the printing of supports and reduce printing times. My opinion is that the new front parts take a lot less time to print, but has reduced height placements, so V2 is actually more functional. I was using this design to do printer calibration (don't like to waste time printing those test cubes..) and now my left front piece is V3 and the right front piece is V2 lol. Will post pic of my frankenstein soon so others can see how it looks like.

There is 4 parts in total. 1,2, 3, and 4.
Print all 4. The v3 are the new front models that were change to lower the amount of support needed

I wanted antijon's hot shoe cover to have my logo inset in it.

Source files included. You'll need to grab HK.dxf and toss it in the same location as the scad file in order to properly import it.

The Fujara is a traditional musical instrument from Slovakia. It's originally a shephard's flute. It is played both with a few (typically 3) finger holes and overblown to get overtones. This version is a 3D printed fipple (the difficult part) that can be attached to cheap standard PVC 1-1/4" waste pipes. The length of the pipe should typically be 50 times the inner diameter of the pipe (1,587 mm).
As you may guess from the filename, it took be six attempts to get the fipple to sound properly.
For adding finger holes, there is a good article at http://www.flutopedia.com/fujara_craft.htm

comments.text: Thanks for this great design. Works well. From unknown reason (perhaps inch-centimeter problem) has to be scaled down to 88.5% to fit slovakian 1-1/4" waste pipes.

comments.text: Thanks! Whatever your local PVC pipe supplier has in stock ;-)

print_settings.Notes:: I originally printed this in PLA, and it does not hold up to the heat in a car interior very well well. If you are going to use this in a car, print in ABS.

title: Surface mount for TechMatte magnetic phone mount

description.text:
I recently bought a TechMatte magnetic vent mounted phone holder (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019GL78NK/ref=od_aui_detailpages00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). It works well, but I wasn't crazy about the vent mount part.

I designed this piece to re-use the magnetic part of the mount, but allow me to mount it to a flat part of my dashboard with two sided tape. The magnetic part of the mount fits over the ball perfectly, even with a coat of primer and two coats of paint on it.

I also designed this piece to work with 3M command strips. I have this attached to my dashboard with a 3M command strip and it works great. It has been holding up for months.

Make sure you use the latest file with the beefed up main shaft. I found that the weight of the mount itself caused the piece to fail in a hot car. The revised design seems to work a lot better.

Notes:

I originally printed this in PLA, and it does not hold up to the heat in a car interior very well well. If you are going to use this in a car, print in ABS.
Depending on your printer, you will definitely have to sand the ball portion down in order to fit cleanly into the magnetic mount and have it work well.

author: schleppy

title: Led holder add-on for Robo3d printer

description.text:
It is a holder for three 5mm leds. It clips on the printer, exactly in front of the extruder head, right behind the sticker "Do not touch". The leds are angled by 10 degrees towards the extruder nozzle and 20 degrees to each other. I would propose using diffusion leds in order to get evenly spread light(I haven't sadly :) ). Mounts firmly by clipping on the plastic above it. Has a hole for the wires to come out on the left hand side, very close to where the cable bundle of the printer ends, so very easy to get the power supply through there. Is rather discreet. I printed mine using 0.2mm layers.
If printed in lower resolution(0.3 or 0.4) they MAY NOT FIT each other, as they are supposed to fit tightly. Push hard, it wont break:) Will update with further photos.

comments.text: Nice little box and lid. Works well and is a good size to work with
comments.author: Jwvanno

comments.text:
Just some feedback on longevity of the part... after 3 months of near constant use of the printer, today the LED holder fell off. One of the two arms had bent... looks like from heat due to proximity next to the hotend. I took a lighter, heated up the arm briefly, bent it back, and clipped it back on. Seems to be holding great again. If you ever redesign the part tho, you may want to consider:
1) Make the arms thicker
2) Make the top of the clips a bit longer (in towards center) so there is more "clip" to the arms for holding in on and in place.

When your astronauts get to their destination what do they find?
This should be a perfect size to put most of your monsters inside of.
I wanted to specifically create something not functional, and just for fun. 
The original idea was to make it an overly complex planter. Now I may sculpt something out of clay to go inside.
nothing moves, though that could be done. Everything is very modular, so components could be swapped out, reused etc.
I also included the openscad file with all the parts. I recommend lowering the sphere resolution for modeling then increasing it again for final render.

print all parts. the big parts require a pretty big print bed unless it's resized.
I assembled parts with hot glue and M3 bolts. None of the hot glue was really required but it allowed me to print attachment components separate from the body so I could swap them out easily without a full reprint.
The cover set assembly has a lot of print support built in that needs to be broken away.
I put covers over the main body and painted it all so that the contrast between the transluscent and black would show.
I also bought a little $2 push light to put inside and shine through the translucent insides.
enjoy.

author: jaymi587

description.text:
If a small movement (10x10mm) with big force and high speed is required the current design is the ideal solution. By using an eccentric and bearing the rotation of the servo is converted into linear movement.

Similar movement of the milling head is used in Shaper tool - https://shapertools.com/

A video showing how the design is working could be found on:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ErpPezxVQ-A

Converting the rotation angle of the servos into Cartesian coordinate system requires some trigonometry calculations.

Trigonometric relations

The calculations are absolutely the same as in double SCARA robot or sometimes called "five bar robot". One really good example which also includes C++ library is listed below:

http://robdobson.com/2015/05/scara-arm-calculations/

The C code (uploaded here as ZIP file) could be found on:
https://developer.mbed.org/users/Bobty/code/SCARA_Arms/

In any case uploaded the image with the formulas below from robdobson.com. You can see that the eccentricity works as the distance "ShoulderToElbow" .

Another good source of trigonometry explanation (which is not directly applicable for SmallXY because elbow = shoulder) is:

http://forum.conceptforge.org/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=184

What could be used for Wally RepRap could be used in the SmallXY calculations.

Another examples of double SCARA:

http://www.3ders.org/articles/20130913-reprap-wally-beta-kit-makes-first-moves.html

http://www.mecademic.com/DexTAR.html

title: 60mm fan duct for UP Plus2 and Afinia

description.text:
I have tried installing several fans in order to reduce the temperature of the step motor of my UP Plus2 printer.

I tried a 40mm fan duct I found here in thingiverse but the design was really bad (don't worry, I will not show up the name). The model itself was well designed for printing, but the author didn't take much care about the physics of fluids. I used a good 40 mm fan and found out that the flow around the step motor was really low, do to the internal design of the model: the flow is not constant, it depends on the pressure; if the pressure at the exit of the fan is high, the flow will be considerably reduced. Translation: the air must have a generous escape door or exit.

So I decided to create my own fan duct. But instead of using the 40 mm fan I bought a 60 mm fan. Increasing 50% the diameter dramatically increases the flow.

Why do you need a fan? I experienced problems when using certain PLA (most of the brands) and noticed that the step motor was very hot, softening the PLA before it should and therefor preventing it from advancing ("clack, clack, clack" noise, you probably know what I mean).

I have not tried many brands of PLA yet, but the ones I have tested seem to work. So something may have improved with this.

Notes:

I have included two versions of the same model. One STL contains the full model and the other has the model divided in two parts which must be glued together later.

Gluing the two parts is a good idea if you want to avoid too much supports, needed for the whole piece.

I have printed it with ABS which allows for a higher temperature (it will be very near the extruder).

After you print it, you just have to screw the fan.

I recommend that you unplug/switch off the 60mm fan if you print with ABS. The duct is designed to lower the temperature of the motor, but the output air flow may slightly cool the ambient temperature surrounding the piece you are printing. So in order to avoid warping... just switch it off.

title: Alignment jig for paralleling two 18650 Lithium cells

description.text:
UPDATE:
I RECOMMEND TO USE THIS NEW VERSION, WHICH IS MUCH SIMPLER AND MORE PRACTICAL TO USE:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170954

When paralleling two 18650 cells by spot welding, it is often challenging to get the nickel strips straight and to precisely hit the poles with the spot welder, especially the smaller plus poles.

This alignment tool is for 7mm wide nickel strip.

How to use:

Insert the batteries and nickel strip into the adapter. Attach cover part. The one with the larger openings if you are welding the minus poles or the one with the smaller openings if you are spot welding the plus poles. Spot weld through the openings, then remove jig.

This is an Arduino-based 3D-printed watch. By not including fancy Wifi and BLE connectivity, it gets several months of run time out of a 160 mAh button cell. The display is an always-on 96 x 96 pixel Sharp Memory LCD. If telling the time is not enough, you can play a simplified version of Flappy Bird on it.

More Information on Hackaday.io: https://hackaday.io/project/12876-chronio

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The parts I made were printed in PLA.
Buttons and cover should be printed with thin layers (<100um).
The case needs to be printed with supports. Simplify3D is not required, but will save you some time needed for removing the supports.

comments.text: You've already mastered the black art of making tiny PC boards.  You should get a hot air station (~$35 US on ebay for one of the Chinese knock offs that got high marks on the EEV blog), and try using some of those QFN packages.  Also consider the SAM21D 32 pin part, same cpu used in the Arduino Zero.  Better clock and low power modes, plus you'll improve the graphics.  I like your idea on that memory display, but it seem that the 96x96 part may be discontinued, the 128x128 is still current on Digikey though.
comments.author: scharkalvin

comments.text:
Thanks! I am definitely planning on making a project with QFN-parts and reflow soldering in the future. Especially with accelerometers there are no other options. But the lack of a proper workbench always keeps me from buying stuff like a hot air station. It is a lot more convenient to just take a regular soldering iron.
An ARM processor would be more fitting for a smartwatch but I wanted to keep it simple and Arduino compatible. If that wasn't a requirement I would have picked an EFM32. Those are made for super low power and even have an integrated timer that can be used to refresh the memory display. I don't know about the display availability. The 96x96 one was just the only one available at Farnell and with the higher resolution ones you run into memory problems with the Atmega328.
An improved watch with proper processor, better display and QFN parts would be a nice project, but I don't know if I will have that much time.
comments.author: scharkalvin

Supports are built into the STL for the required parts. Make sure you have your slicer detect thin walls (I use Slic3r), or they may be missed.

Printed in ABS 230C extruder, 110C heated bed, in a sealed chamber, 5mm brim. Paused the print right after the brim and before the first layer contours, then applied super-glue where the first layer contours were to be printed. Bed adhesion was so good it actually pulled a few shards of glass of the bed when removing. Zero warping, though.

Removed support materials with a small curved file, cleared the holes with a small rounded file, and sanded the flat surfaces with a sanding block. The air pipe was a little work, but i eventually got it clean.

Also forgot to model a little clip on the exhaust of the fan, but a little filing fixed it easy.
This is mostly spaghetti code on OpenSCAD. For the HCAD/* libraries check my github repository.

title: replacement temple for nana-nator over your glasses sunglasses

description.text:
I keep a pair of sunglasses in the car (http://www.solarshield.com/) but the temples usually snap in half after a while. So I finally got around to 3D printing a replacement. I also used HIPS to support an ABS print on my dual extruders. The supports need work. They more or less failed when I tried to print. But well enough to get one good temple to keep me going. TO DO:
Improve supports (stabilize, maybe with some rocket like fins)
Shorten slightly (the one I printed doesn't quite close cleanly)
cut out between top peg and bottom as that would be where the other temple's other end would rest. So two of these won't quite fold properly.

Print with ABS at 235C and HIPS at 235C on 115C platform.  
100% infill no automatic support  
I wasn't able to get MakerWare to slice this, I had to use ReplicatorG/Skeinforge.  
Use "r2b" versions, they are newer, slightly shorter with better supports.

title: '97-'06 Jeep Automatic Shift Indicator Lower Bracket

description.text:
This is a replacement for the bottom of the Indicator Assembly on a TJ Jeep Wrangler with an automatic.

The holes that are molded in the top cover bosses are too large for the #6 screws as molded. Fill these bosses with epoxy, let cure & drill them out with a 1/8" bit. After which you can mount this printed bottom to the top bezel with #6 x 1/2" thread forming screws.

Note: if your bottom posts broke off inside the bosses like mine did, you may have to drill out the broken bottom posts that are left inside the bosses first, then fill bosses with epoxy.

author: daveyclk

title: Flying Lego Batman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What could be better than Batman?!

Lego Batman, that's what!

This guy stands at about 6inches tall with a 1.5 foot wingspan, the wingspan has been calculated to he can actually fly / glide like a bird

The wing frames are to be lined with a thin black plastic, like a bin liner

The print begins tonight and should be complete in 18 hours!

There are 2 versions of the minifigure, one complete solid body, and one made up of all the separate arms, legs etc so you can have full articulation. The parts are designed to press/snap fit together. If you want to add a little Cragle to make sure it stays together after crashing then that's your Lord Business.

I have a few renders for now, should look pretty cool!

This will need to be printed with supports and as it's quite large a 0.2mm layer height and a 20% infill is recommended

author: daveyclk

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:78727

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=78727

Using the following options:

label_text = Book Drawing
font = write/knewave.dxf
build_plate_selector = 3
build_plate_manual_y = 280
build_plate_manual_x = 298

I wanted something to hold my nook while I'm seated or in bed so that my arms don't get tired for watching movies.  
I figured I could use dowels for the long bits. But I should've chosen thicker ones. The current design bows/sways a bit too much.

Each joint is three pieces plus a nut and a bolt. The dowel pieces are held in by friction. The teeth on the circular part limit sliding. The three-pointed piece is to make it easy to tighten and loosen the joints.  
I printed two joints, plus a few extra pieces to attach to the nook clamp. Also, the desk clamp will need a three-pointed piece and a long bolt plus a nut. I don't think I made the slot for the nut big enough. I had to "encourage" it into place by heating/pushing with a soldering iron.  
I recommend printing the joint pieces at 45 degrees with support so that the "grain" of the print adds to the strength of the part, rather than giving the pieces an obvious place to break.  
You'll need nuts and bolts to screw them together. When I relocate the nuts and bolts, I'll post exactly which size.  
Print everything but the clamp with 100% infill. The clamp needs to be stronger, and will need to be redesigned. It works OK, but fails if you over tension it.  
I dipped the ends of the actual holder bracket in some latex so the Nook won't slide out.  
clamp1d has a channel vertically through the spine of the clamp to add some material/reinforce that area. We'll see if that helps. The first one cracked after repeated use.

comments.text: I can confirm that this works for the Nook HD. Thanks! A derivative of this design should be coming soon

description.text:
I wanted a keyset for my mechanical keyboard that resembled the old school typewriters. I decided to design my own that I could change and customize as desired. These were designed for Cherry MX switches.

Each key is two parts. The main piece and an insert. Since I have a single filament machine and wanted to have multiple colors this was my solution.

I did not break the key inserts down into rows or groups so the attached STL is likely to large for most beds but should be easily broken down. I am also working on the larger keys and space bar for this design.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select IIIP

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I had the best luck printing the keys with the stem down.

I printed mine in PLA so if you are printing ABS you may need to scale up.

description.text: Simple push on Filament Guide for the MakerFarm Prusa i3

Check out our Etsy for all of our 3D printed awesomeness!
https://www.etsy.com/shop/3DCentral

You can buy this sword fully built on our Etsy! Find it here: http://etsy.me/2c6wA3m

It's Pearl's Spear from Steven Universe! One of the coolest weapons of the Crystal Gems, Pearl's spear is sleek, shiny, and really awesome! Print one out today!

We split the blade and handle into separate segments for easy printing, but we also included the full models if you want to cut them custom yourself! (or if you have a giant 3D printer! :P )

Check out a build video by Andrew Sink: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oFHt3yoVzhU&t=1s

Print out the following pieces:

WHITE:
Handle_1.stl
Handle_2.stl
Handle_3.stl
Pin.stl x 5
Hilt_Pin.stl

BLUE:
Blade_1.stl
Blade_2.stl
Blade_3.stl
Blade_4.stl
Blue_Pommel_1.stl
Blue_Pommel_2.stl
Blue_Hilt.stl

YELLOW:
Yellow_Pommel.stl

The blades all fit together using the connecting pins; use some super glue to keep them firmly connected. Use the longer Hilt_Pin to connect the blade through the Blue_Hilt and into the handle, which is also connected in sequence.

Connect Handle_3 into Blue_Pommel_1, then connect to Yellow_Pommel, then glue both to Blue_Pommel_2. That's it, good to go!

title: Defender Ship USB Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This a drive case designed to look like a classic Defender ship with 3d representation, it is wide so if you have a lot of devices it can be annoying as it may limit how many usb ports can actually be used. So print one yourself and blast some aliens as you move data from place to place!


If you would like to support my 3d modeling efforts or would like to show appreciation for this model please use my paypal address.

Paypal address: [email protected]

No emails please! Thank you!

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Resolution:

High

Infill:

15 - 20% (Your choice I did 15%)

Assembly

Okay, this maybe hard to explain but here goes, first you break open your current drive, that you wish to put in the Defender ship, then you pull out the metal part with the chip in it, and stick it on the lower part of the defender ship. Then you stick the upper piece (smaller piece) on top making sure not to let the metal part fall out. After that, you hot glue the upper piece to the metal part, pull it off and let it cool, then you put glue on the bottom of the upper piece and put the upper piece back on the lower piece where the lines are, being careful to line up the pixels. And finally, you seal the whole thing by putting glue around the outside of the upper piece where it touches the lower piece (Optional. I did it just to be sure it wouldn't break.)


Now, your Defender USB is done, enjoy and thank you for reading this! ;)

How I Designed This

I copied the pixels from a photograph. And then, I did my own representation on what they looked like by making them 3D. And finally, I cut holes where the USB stick goes. Then I printed it 3 times to work out bugs.

author: rootyjr

description.text:
The Hilbert Curve is a space filling fractal curve. It is a recursive process that eventually fills the entire space using one continuous line. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_curve for more information.

This thing holds the STL-files for the first four recursion levels. Although normally the outer space of the cube is held constant, I decided to keep the length of the line fragments constant such that it can be well printed at all level. One could manually resize the figure if one wishes.

There had to be made some concessions to the design to give it enough stability. In particular there are several small vertical support lines and a few horizontal. Otherwise the figure cannot be printed or would soon collapse.

Level 1: 7 line fragments, 12x12x12mm
Level 2: 63 line fragments, 28x28x28mm
Level 3: 511 line fragments, 60x60x60mm
Level 4: 4095 line fragments, 124x124x124mm

Note: The picture is created using POV-ray.

Doesn't Matter

description.text:
I recently upgraded my Prusa P3Steel from threaded rods to leadscrews which I had to design some parts for (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1592451).

I got few requests for some variants so I figured I'd bite the bullet and learn some OpenSCAD to make things a bit more parametric! (I'm a professional programmer in my working life so this seemed like a useful thing to pick up)

These parts have been designed from scratch in OpenSCAD and I have tried to expose variables to help customise the parts to your needs. The files are still WIP, so expect frequent changes, but I think I'm mostly happy with the output (if not the code itself!).

WIP

I'll be editing these files a lot, and posting pictures up when I get round to printing them, but I wanted to get these out as I've had a number of requests for the parts.

Changes:

10-Feb-2017

  • Added a hasBearingDivider boolean to turn the divider on and off more easily.
  • Corrected some minor spelling mistakes in the scad file comments

16-Nov-2016

  • Updated the XTensor to be a bit easier to print (especially with ABS)
  • Added a pre-compiled XTensor stl file

07-Nov-2016

  • Shortened the name of source files
  • Made 18mm and 17mm STL files for convenience, scad file defaults to 18mm (refers to value of variable distanceBetweenLinearBearingAndLeadRod)

30-Oct-2016

  • Fixed a minor bug that caused the motor centre to be off by 1mm in the Z axis (thanks to @emphacy for pointing that out!). Don't worry if you've already printed though, this is more of an aesthetic fix
  • Also fixed a minor issue that caused the X-Stop mount to ever so slightly take up some screw void space

3-Oct-2016

  • Fixed a bug in both the .scad and .stl files were the vertical linear rod centre and leadscrew centre were off by 0.5mm in the X axis. They should now be exactly 18mm from centre to centre with the default value.

9-Sep-2016

  • First release

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa P3Steel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I've not actually printed these parts yet, so I'll post up some shots once I have.

OpenSCAD files

I have uploaded some .stl files with default values but you can edit a bunch of parameters in the OpenSCAD source files to hopefully get what you're after.

You'll need OpenSCAD installed to edit the files, but once opened there's a bunch of comments detailing what parameters you may want to edit do. There's also some boolean options to turn on and off parts as well as an option for the 2 kinds of Lead rod bearings i've come across.

Alignment

The most requested change I've been asked about is Linear bearing/Lead rod alignment.

For alignment, in the .scad files you're going to want to take a look at the variables:

distanceBetweenLinearBearingAndLeadRod = 18;
leadRodYaxisOffset = 0;

These control the x/y offset of the rods from each other. If you've got some wild alignment differences in the Y axis, you may also need to take a look at changing:

distanceBetweenSmoothRodAndLinearBearing = 15;

Bearing type

The 2nd most requested feature is bearing type compatibility.

From what I've managed to gather, there are 2 major bearing types (stick some more examples in the comments if there's other common one's out there!)

  1. A brass style bearing with 4 equally spaced holes for attaching (I have this type)
  2. A plastic/delrin style bearing with 3 equally spaced holes for attaching

You can swap between the different bearing types by changing the following variable:

leadRodBearingType = 0;

A value of 0 gives the brass style, a value of 1 gives the plastic style.

Other optional features

The Motor mount part .scad file has 3 boolean values that you can set to add/remove features.

They are:

hasZStopScrew = true; // Setting this to true will add a section add a screw you can use to adjust z-stop min
hasXStopMount = true; // Setting this to true will add a mount for a X-min switch
hasCableChainMount = true; // Setting this to true will add 2 holes above the motor section to attach a cable chain mount

Notes
  • I tend to go a bit narrow with screw hole radius (I like to tap them to get a good thread)
  • The .stl files were rendered with $fn=128 for a smoother finish on curves (files default to 32 because it's faster to render when its WIP)
  • The previous parts I designed as a remix from other parts had the X smooth rods exposed a little, these new parts do away with that and enclose the smooth rods entirely, which should hopefully allow leadscrew bearings to sit on the part without needing to file an edge down!
  • I initially designed these parts specifically for my p3Steel XL, however since they're now more parametric, they should work well with any Prusa i3 variant if you want to use Leadscrews

title: Cl-260 Tuning Printhead / XY-Carrier for LM8LUU

description.text:
New Cl-260 printhead carrier for 2xLM8LUU linear ball bearings
Much more rigid and more precise than original part
Compatible with all E3D V6 and E3D V5 Heatbreaks
LM8UU version of the belt tensioner/carrier is available here:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1761063

Has a second set of M3-holes, which can be used to mount an small direct drive extruder on top of it, to extrude TPU, TPE and other filaments which don't work well in a bowden setup.

title: Tweety 2.0 - 130 Sized -True X - FPV Racing POD

description.text:
130 Sized Quadcopter frame for FPV Racing.`
--- PROJECT FINALIZED ---
uploaded a new frame : 130_True_X.Emerged.Motors.Frame.II.STL

  • up to 19mm outer dia. motors -

There whas a small design flaw in the previous. The frame wasnt geometrical at left/right side..
Also did big cutouts in the arms to reduce frame weight ..

This frame is realy rigid and durable won't break easy, printed @100% infill ABS..

p.s. IF YOU DOWNLOAD THIS PROJECT, PLEASE LIKE !!

After a few request for bigger motor sizes i just finished a version of the frame wich accomodates up to 19mm outer diameter motors.

This is the frame, VTX holder, Buzzer Module, Cam Dome, battery holder and standoffs.

See foto's :
Carbon: 187 grams without battery ( 256 with battery (3s 850MAh) )
New Frame: 45 grams. Weight w/o battery 180 grams.

VTX holder fits most TS5xxx VTX-es ...

title: Machine-Flower, Bodum Latte 8oz Cup Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My favorite coffee cups and my personal cup holder. Bodum Pavina Double Wall Tumbler - 8 oz and the Machine-Flower.

This design incorporates the mechanization and the organic curvature possible with additive manufacturing. The flower and the gear cradle your caffeine in a safe embrace, for when you are able to put down the tools or the mouse and take a sip.

Suggest gluing or double sided tape securing a Machine flower in areas spilling is a bit more of a disaster than others. Soldering station, anywhere near electronics, are not good places to spill the coffee. These holders can be used as free roaming artistic kitchenware or as secured cup holders for high risk situations.

They stack well, wash well if printed with enough infill to use everyday, I think I used something like 50%.

I hope you enjoy them!

Printer:

MiltyKoss Delta, Monoprice i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

as low as you can wait for, kitchen products should have a fine surface quality for easy cleaning and visual appeal.

Infill:

max you can stand to wait for, so they hold up when hand washing in the sink.

Notes:

These holders fit the Bodum 'Pavina' Double Wall Tumbler - 8 oz.

Design to fit...

A camera and a image editor are good tools for matching curvature between the real world and your CAD software.

Use a thin slice of the model to verify curvature matching with a quick to print prototype of only the area you need to check.

Never settle for 'whatever' get the shape and structure you intended, even if you have to step back from frustration and try again in the morning.

Happy designing y'all :o)

author: hugobav

title: EC5 Connector to IEC Cutout Pico PSU 12v

description.text:
This is a simple and clean design that let's you take out the IEC connector for an AC input and replace it with this adapter to let you take a regular EC5 connector for hobby batteries and glue the connector in this adapter (As shown in the pictures) so that a Pico PSU has a neat way and reliable way of getting power from a 12 volt source like a Lead Acid battery or a 3s Lipo or even in my case a old 12v Dell PSU for an micro-itx build. I don't trust that little barrel connector Pico PSUs come with because really 5 amps is tops but they pull way beyond that, I'm also pretty sure that it would just eventually unplug itself someday being a small and being an un-tight fit in the connector and really piss me off.

I know that the connector is overkill; the whole point is to make a reliable and somewhat trip over a cord and not get pulled out of the connector kinda deal.

author: robertmaks

title: Scissor Snake Easy Grip Custom
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Description:
Enables people with limited use of their hands to manipulate small objects at a distance in a fun and effective way. Also make a fun toy. Includes 7 head shapes and 5 handles in different sizes you can combine in any combination to suit your needs. Tailor the handle to fit the user, and the head to fit the task, so the tool functions as an adaptor extending the range of tasks performable by disabled users. Instantly increases physical reach by up to 12″. One tester said it gave him “a super-power to reach things.” If you need a different size or shape end, just ask and I’ll be glad to add it to the collection.

Prints without support and comes off the build plate ready to use.

How to Customize Import one head design and one handle design, along with the middle [‘SSEGv0_-Middle.stl’] into your slicer. Depending on your software and settings, you may need to align the parts to form a complete scissor snake. Don’t worry, that’s easy… in Simplify3D, select all three models and choose ‘Edit|Align Selected Model Origins’. You’ll see the see the part register properly. In Makerware and Slicr, the models should come in already aligned. If you reposition them, just make sure all three models are selected first so they move together.

How to print the Scissor Snake Prints easily on most printers. Be sure to use a clean and level build plate. Print at 0.2 mm layer height and 30% infill or greater, with 3 or 4 parameters for strength. You can tighten up the action by scaling down the parts by 5% to 10%. If your print is too tight, or fuses, you can increase the clearance by increasing the scale by 5% to 10%. https://youtu.be/x_zPq1aS5h0

Printer:

Duplicator 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Requires clean and level build plate. Use cooling fan if available. For a tighter action, scale the part down slightly. For looser action, scale the part up slightly. Will work with up to 100% infill for the best strength.

comments.text: Do the various handles and heads snap onto the middle?
comments.author: GoldenWelding

comments.text: No, you have to pick a handle and head, and load them with the middle into your slicer. When you place the parts on your build plate they probably won't be registered properly until you use 'align by origin' (depending on your slicer, I show images in the posting on how to do it in simplify3d) and they will position the parts so they will print all at once. All the parts have the same origin when assembled. Thanks, please let me know if that doesn't work for you. Thanks.
comments.author: GoldenWelding

title: Fan Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE: The V5 STL is FIXED and now has the hole in the duct removed so you don't need to cut it out.
This was a Colaboration between myself and a friend in Fusion 360.
The joint between the fan duct and the outlet duct may need to be cut out with a dremel as I did not get the chance to remove it in the final after tweaking a few things. If i get the chance and inclination I may update it at some stage.

You also may need to measure and adjust the height to suite your printer. My outlet sits about 1mm above my nozzle.

The duct was designed to fit on this
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1511554
thanks jowjowjow for the base :) prints and works a treat!

title: 40mm Blower Fan to 40mm Axial Fan Adapter

description.text:
Simple adapter to mount 40mm blower fan to a regular 40mm fan slot. I had some 40mm blower fan around and was curious to see if these blower fan will perform better than the conventional axial fan in cooling the feed stepper motor.
I have test printed it and everything fits fine, however I have not test its cooling effectiveness.

Some good read: http://www.pelonistechnologies.com/blog/axial-vs.-centrifugal-fans

Printer:

Malyan M180

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 Micron

Infill:

15%-20%

author: DaeHyuk

print_settings.Notes:: On glass use glue at corners.

description.text:
I have now finished fine tuning this design and it appears to work well. There are two filter versions, one for pad filters and one for holding activated charcoal. Using it with either filter type and either orientation seems to work fine.

This print takes 24 hours with my settings for the main body and about 3-4 hours for each filter part. Only the part with tab overhangs requires support. For my Anet A8 printer it uses the full bed width, if your bed is smaller you may be able to scale the parts down a bit.

There doesn't seem to be interest in other fan versions yet so I won't do that version unless I hear otherwise.

Good luck if you decide to make it and feel free to ask questions.

This was inspired by this one...by "nrp"
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17086

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

On glass use glue at corners.

The fan I used was one I had around that I had gotten from a surplus store.
Sony SFF22C
10 VDC 0.15A
38 CFM 1.076m3/min

The sealing gasket I used is premium rubber insulating tape, 5mm x 9mm, from the hardware store.

description.text:
I got a bit (a lot really) pissed off with the CRAP Bunnings sells here in Oz - masonry anchors that don't grip - they either fall out or rotate when the screw is tightened

Here is my version that works really well for me - PLUS - if the size is a tad out - just print one that is right - it only takes a few minutes.

They even have the size printed on the bottom - although it's a bit hard to read on the smaller sizes:-)

Printed with ABS - although PETG would be more flexibl, useful if the hammer veers a bit sideways

author: DaeHyuk

title: Dice Tower with Secret Chamber for Dice Storage

description.text:
EDIT: 9/25/16
I have updated the bridge and the trap door parts. The new bridge doesn't let dice jump out so easily, but they still can if you drop them from above the tower.

Thanks to the makers (FluffyB and RaunoProps) who gave input for improving this.

Thanks to 3E8 for suggesting the under stairs hole expansion. I probably wouldn't have tried it otherwise.

UPDATE: 1/17/2017
Pu1p made a flagpole for the secret door switch. Check it out: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2043609

comments.text: I got the robo3d r1 for christmas and this is my first real print other than some test prints. It came out great and I'm hooked on 3d printing now. I made this for my wife. We play a lot of board games. The translucent purple looks good.
comments.author: tapkar

comments.text: Great job... looks really nice!  However, I would really like to see this in a modular tower variant for smaller 3d printers like my Monoprice Mini, etc.  Also, to be able to add more " tower sections" for a longer dice drop.
comments.author: Grejam53

comments.text: You're the second person to ask for the modular design.  The problem is the stair layout.  It's not really practical with the hidden compartment.  It would be an entirely new design to do it.
comments.author: Grejam53

comments.text: Hey there! I love how this all printed, but unfortunately my turret and trapdoor both have holes that are too small to go with the tower. Even with force, the pegs on the tower are simply too large. I see that nobody else has had this problem so I'm wondering if files were revised since their builds? I looked into resizing the pieces, but when I layout what has already been printed, everything is in the right scaling.
comments.author: jmulli

comments.text: Sorry about the trouble, I drilled mine out with a hand drill I use for miniatures.  The tolerance is tight, but it's really just a guide.  Once you align it properly and glue it you shoud be good.  I snapped two off my first one, but it glued on ok anyway. I oversized the drill on the second one.  They probably need sanding too.
comments.author: jmulli

comments.text: Okay not a problem! I'm still new to printing so I just wanted to make sure it wasn't me.
comments.author: brimstone326

comments.text: Cool.  Good luck and I hope it turns out.
comments.author: jmulli

comments.text: I printed one out and it ends up the talk of the DnD table everytime! Only downsides are the dice pop out a little too often and the drawbridge doesn't have any kind of catch to keep it closed during transportation.
comments.author: kokusho

comments.text: I'm glad you like it.  I don't see you on the list of Makes, so I may have revised parts since you printed yours.  Did you print rev 4 of the drawbridge? It is as high as I can make it and not change the base tower.  It seems to help a lot.
comments.author: kokusho

comments.text: Yeah i printed pretty recently, only just registered with thingiverse. I did use the rev 4 version. The dice don't fliy out all the time, just more often then i would prefer. Sometimes the DnD adventure is exciting and the die gets tossed in quicker then normal lol.
comments.author: brimstone326

comments.text: Ok, so I added a kokusho_drawbridge file.  It has a lip with a chamfer that has essentially zero clearance at the fully closed position.  You are welcome to give it a shot and let me know how it goes.  I won't be printing it to test.  My towers are painted and I don't want to mess them up.  Thanks for adding the make.
comments.author: kokusho

comments.text: Would you be able to add the brick pattern to the turret?
comments.author: scrid2000

comments.text: Done.  Good idea... file is turret_V2
comments.author: scrid2000

comments.text: Wow that was fast, thanks!
comments.author: brimstone326

comments.text: No problem.
comments.author: scrid2000

comments.text: Finally got it all printed out.. the dice jump out about 50% of the time.
comments.author: maestro72x

comments.text: I just added a rev4 drawbridge.  It's as big as it can get and not interfere with anything.  I'm going to print one and will test it out.  I just hope the weight is distributed enough that it will stay closed when raised.  I added a couple images.
comments.author: maestro72x

comments.text: ok great lmk how it works out.
comments.author: brimstone326

comments.text: Posted pics, it's better, but not perfect.  My 20 sided die shot out of it the first time, but I was throwing dice down the shoot and all the others stayed in.  To really fix it, I'd have to make the entry way longer so the drawbridge could be uniform height.
comments.author: maestro72x

comments.text: Great that you got it printed out!
comments.author: maestro72x

comments.text: i think the stairs need to be sloped at a lesser angle. I tried many ways of putting them in but 50% the time they jump out.. Im sure a heavier die will help but these are generic die from Catan.
comments.author: brimstone326

comments.text: I'm not sure.  There isn't a slope at all actually, they just drop down in 5mm increments.  I use Chessex dice for D&D, and generally don't have issues, but I will admit it isn't perfect.  I'll see if I can come up with an alternative to not have to make a new tower.

comments.text: Can u make inside wall like a cell?

comments.text: Probably, but I think I saw a version like that already.

comments.text: They just have bars.. you can do a door w lock etc.. your tower is much better.. you could also put a  pedestal w  statue,, skeleton, chest etc...

comments.text: Well, I'm an engineer not an artist... I can probably manage a barred gate, but much more than that and I'd have to borrow it from another source.  I didn't make the dragon logo, it was a clip art I used Inkscape on and then pulled it into my drawing.  I have another project in the works at the moment.  You are welcome to make your own remix.  I'll see what I can do.

comments.text: The door definetly needs sanding, but I'm not going to use ut, So I'll just put it in locked position. One thing though - it's hard to turn the knob. You should make it flatter so it's easier to turn.

comments.author: fredlock007

comments.text: I really like this... is it solid underneath the staircase?  It'd be nice if you could open it up and maybe have a smooth-and-still-printable surface underneath the steps so you can place more things inside the secret area.
comments.author: 3E8

comments.text: It is solid.  I left it that way because I couldn't think of a good way to cut it on an arc and make it still printable.  I don't use loft a lot in solid works.. and it doesn't always come out right.  I'll give it a shot and see if I can maximize the space and maintain the integrity.  I used slic3r to set up the runs on these and used 3 wall thickness, 0.2 layers, 3 bottom solid layers, and 6 top.  At 10% infill, it looked like it would be ok.  So you wouldn't necessarily be using a lot of plastic.
comments.author: 3E8

description.text: I like the original Ring-A-Thing except for it's chunkiness and completely separate pin. I decided to save a little plastic and revised the design slightly to eliminate the chunkyness, save some plastic and make it a little more "delicate" for small hands. I wish OpenScad had a filet feature. UPDATE I added a second scad file and stl. This one has a shorter peg for less plastic and less bulky charms...unfortunately the charms are incompatible with the original Pin based Ring-A-Thing. I'll upload a negative pin hole stl later for this version. I've put this one together at the request of my son. and I didn't want a lightning bolt sitting on a huge pillar of plastic.

Print and put on a "charm" form the Original Ring-A-Thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17508) or the Heart Charm (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17534). Edit the ring size in the scad file and regenerate STL for a proper fitting ring. The one included here is 21 mm (male adult size)). NOTE: Updated the scad and STL - added rounded edges.

description.text:
Octo-Man was inspired by a similar wood toy that used cubes for each joint. By using Octotoads (that's what they are called in wings3d) it is much more poseable.
You will need some 1/16" elastic chord to connect the parts. NOTE: I realized that the .thing file has an older version of the feet that had squared-off cavities, while the stl files have cavities with angled ceilings that should print better without support.
Also, I have not tried it yet, but scaling everything up just a bit and using 1/8" elastic cord might make for a longer-lasting toy.

You will need to some 1/16" elastic chord (about 3/4 yard). It is available at almost any craft or fabric store. Print all the parts using the octoman thing, or you can add the stl files individually as needed. I scaled the STL object by 600% in the printing software. 12 Joints
2 Feet
1 Hips
1 Torso
1 Head there are 4 pieces of chord...
one from hand to hand through the torso.
one from each foot up through the hips. x2
one through the hips torso and head. For each section, tie a big knot (I use 2 or three simple knots on top of each other) then string the parts onto the cord. Then stretch the cord as tight as possible and use something to hold the cord tight while you tie the knot for the other end. I used some tweezers that let me lodge the cord tight into it while I tied a big knot in the other end. The knots should be big enough to keep the cord from slipping through, but small enough to lodge in the cavity.
I also used just a drop of super-glue on each knot. Have fun!

description.text:
This is a version of my Minimalistic Phone Stand only for larger tablets. Like the phone stand it was designed to only require one stand to keep the tablet/phone upright, but using more then one is always an option. It still small enough to stick in your pocket or put in your tablet case and carry with you, without taking up any room. Like the original there are 5 versions to try and accommodate different tablet sizes with and without cases. I had to beef up the design on this version as the heavier, larger tablets were flexing the stand.

A=11mm
B=12mm
C=13mm
D=14mm
E=15mm

If you have a phone or tablet that is larger or smaller then what I have then let me know and I'll try to make one for your setup. If you download and use this please leave a comment saying which one you used and what phone/tablet/case setup you have to let others know. Thanks and I hope you enjoy.

My phone stand can be found here

description.text:
These models are intended to be slipped over some 1" EMT conduit.

I found a number of models for recreating Rey's Staff from The Force Awakens, but I wasn't happy with the fidelity or accuracy of the ones I found. I made up names for the components as I went along, but you can use the 'Assembly' model to figure out where everything goes or the included screen capture of the assembly.

The sling on screen appears to be a pair of Lee-Enfield slings stitched and buckled together. Lobster clasps were attached to either end and a custom H-shaped leather piece was used to attach to the staff.

Sling: http://amzn.to/2cMyWEt
Clasp: http://amzn.to/2cBha2u
D-Ring: http://amzn.to/2cioEq5

comments.text:
Does anyone know the total weight of all the components? (i.e. NOT including the wood dowel/strap/leather grip)
My local library charges $0.10/gram and I want to figure out if it will be cost effective to print there.
Thanks!
comments.author: NicoleM

comments.text: Assuming a shell thickness of 0.80mm and an infill density of 30%, the total weight of all printed parts should be between 48 and 58 grams, depending on if you are printing in PLA or ABS. Add some margin in there for support material and you'd be looking at between $50 and $60 I'd say.

comments.text: I don't know what typical print speeds are for a MakerBot, but I printed my pieces individually at 40 to 70 mm/s and 0.2mm/layer (0.1mm for the amulets). Most pieces took me 90 minutes to print, with the tall pieces taking at least 3 hours each, so for me the total print time was like 40 hours... I'm sure that if these were printed as a batch you could cut some time off.

comments.text: I'm curious if you had any trouble printing the piece you called "Amulet."  I only tried once this morning, but it printed about a quarter inch, and then the piece broke loose form the platform. There's a number of issues that could have caused this with such a small surface area contacting the platform, such as the platform needing to be re-leveled, or the build tape needing to be replaced.  Or it just could have been bad luck. So I'm curious what your experience was like printing this piece.

remixed_from.author: auralgasm
remixed_from.title: Center Bed Leveler for MP Select Mini

title: MP Select Mini - Center Bed Leveler

description.text:
This thing is based off of the center bed leveler by auralgasm. This design works by using the screw to push the center of the bed up because it has a tendency to bow downward in a bowl shape, making it difficult to level the center with the extreme edges.

When I printed the original design, I found that the screw length was longer than the threaded hole in the "stick". This meant that I could not tighten the screw all the way in because it would come out the other side of the hole and actually cause the leveler to increase in height instead of decrease. For my printer, I needed the minimum height to level the center of the bed.

All I've done here is cut 0.89 mm off of the length of the screw. Credit goes to auralgasm for the original concept and design.

Monoprice MP Select Mini

description.text: A spring loaded pen holder to attach to an extruder base.

I designed this so I could play about with plotting without taking the extruder off, not ideal but thought it may be of some interest. The pen is secured by the clamp and the whole assembly screwed to the extruder base. The pen is then positioned so it is touching the printing plate and the Z end-stop adjusted accordingly. See comments below for software to drive it.
Build Instructions.
Print the two parts. Saw out the supporting struts and maybe tidy up so the two halves slide together nicely, add an elastic band to spring load the action. Add a nut and bolt for the pen clamp, and self tapping screw to fix the holder to the extruder base.

line_1 = Prof. C.G.Wilson

Ever have a pile of old PCIe x2 x4 x8 x16 cards lying around? They're either scattered on the floor, crammed into a drawer or hidden in the refrigerator with next to the frozen blueberries (yes, I live in a very interesting household). Anyways, you're tired of staring at them and ya don't wanna throw 'em out because you must've paid at least 20 bucks for that old NIC card from 10 years ago and it just still 'feels' useful. I get you brother... I get you.

OK, so let's tidy things up by printing out some display standoffs! That way, when your spouse comes in and sees how neatly you've decorated the place with nigh-worthless computer parts, he (or she) doesn't have to passive-aggressively hint how you need to go outside more often. I made this so that your marriage won't fall apart like mine did.

... Sadness.

On the positive side, this is the first thing I've printed in 3 months! My Wanhao Duplicator 4 is now a pile of rubble as it has been triumphantly replaced by a Flashforge. Yes, this makes me quite happy. Happy indeed. :)

So, this one goes the length of a x8, but of course you can pretty much put any size in it.

If you found this useful, please share your work and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

Sept 13, 2016 update: Published a derivative with the bracket support and curved corners:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1768568

Jan 13th, 2017 update: Added a Generic Card Holder that doesn't have a notch so you can essentially put any card in it.

This is a guide for a closet door... this guides 2 doors to slide in front / behind each other to access one side of a closet or another. This is not for "bi-fold" doors... it is for closets with 2 large doors which overlap in the center and can slide left and right in front / behind each other.

This bracket mounts on the floor (if on a carpet, it likely has spacers underneath the screw holes (~5/8" tall round plastic tubes the screw goes through) to keep it at the at the correct height on the carpet.

I modeled this off an existing (broken) bracket, and it is nearly identical to the original, with similar angles and rounded edges... but it's stronger than the original and works great. I designed 6 small recesses on the bottom to more easily remove it from the hotbed of the printer.

See linked image for example.

title: Spiral moving fish
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When I published Moving fish, someone said: "Could you coil up the fish to allow more segments?"

Coiling up the fish needs Archimedean spiral as a base. The original code of Moving fish is quick and dirty so I have to refactor it. The joint between segments also needs some modification. This is a good request. I learned much from it.

You may use the model with 3 segments to test your printer. If it's printed successfully, a fish with more segments is basically not a problem.

The number 99 reaches the limit of my 3D printer.

.

And, what's the limit of your printer? :)

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

comments.text: Cute design. I'll post a make in a moment. One thing I did note is that if you increase n_multi_3_segments high enough, the pieces near the head will end up being printed "inside" some of the tail pieces. description.text:
FOR HOLD RIGHT / DRAW LEFT !

And that's exactly stunning from statistical point of view: 1,5 times higher download rate compared to the 'hold left/draw right version' , it should be at least reverse...that's worth a scientific investigation!

(Learn more about the story of the Semi-Tube Slingshot and its performance at http://www.slingshotforum.com. Search for 'aiping'!)

Same like Semi-Tube & Tube Slingshot:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1740720
BUT flashlight/arrow plug-in holder diameter changed from 14 to 8 mm and
a M8 hexnut inlay. So now you can attach your own homebrew, what ever it is
at the front or the back, ex. wrist brace, whisker biscuit, flashlight, camera etc.
IMPORTANT: print with ABS 100% infill, 0,3 mm layer. Than this thing is rock-solid, 85 gram.

Feature Summery

Oval fork cones allow to attach flat bands up to 9 cm wide
Detailed procedure you can find here:
http://slingshotforum.com/topic/50425-semi-tube-slingshot-pouchband-attachment/
Tests with multilayer TBB (blue&black) showed that single layer TBS/TBG should be no problem.

Tube channel with clip slot for single or looped tubes. IMPORTANT: Please secure
the Clip-Slot with 5+ tight windings of office rubber in the Semi-Tube groove.
(Like in the main picture the green office rubber)
Steel ball dispenser up to 13 mm, prepared to glue in a magnetic disk diameter 10 mm / hight 5 mm
8 mm fork axis for M8 thread rod plus M8 hexnut inlay for multi purpose
Tilted fork to support a straight fist
Warning! This slingshot is only for experienced shooters, draw at least 5 times effective
band length.

Use of this slingshot at your own risk, especially full butterfly!

LEGAL&SECURITY: Only print and use this slingshot according to the legal regulations of your country. NEVER EVER shoot at humans, even not point and aim. ALWAYS use protective glasses. I strongly suggest a catch box made at least from 15 mm plywood, 20 cm dense plastic foam or 1 mm steel. Don't shoot at concrete or brick walls due to violent ricochets, which can seriously injure yourself or bystanders, of course damage windows, flat screens etc. Only shoot as far as you are able to see, aim AND hit your target.

Slingshot orientation: Ball dispenser AWAY from your body, touching the inner index finger. The flat bands are directed from the grove to the end of the fork cones. This version is for hold RIGHT and draw LEFT handed.

EXPERIMENTAL hard Wrist-brace. It does the job, fits well (for me). 'Design' by function...

Cool is different, I call it 'Tele-tubby crutch', see the 3D view and you understand.

Actually the torque can only be blocked with the 'OpSource'.

Can only be used fork tilted at least 45 degrees, this version is for draw right / hold left.

A wrist sweat towel for tennis will make it more comfortable.

LEGAL DISCLAIMER: There are countries / states where a wrist brace for slingshots
is prohibited by law. Please check carefully if this is the case for your country / state.
If so, I strongly suggest not to download it!

da Vinci 1.0

Notes:

ABS !

This tool will help you develop your proper tennis serve motion, timing and power. It really works wonders.
This is what it supposed to do and this design replaces the socks that are shown on the video, see this guy's explanation how to use it https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oVh7tsa2R6I
The grip size of this design is 4 3/8 or G3.

Printer:

Wombot Exilis

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

300 micron or less

Infill:

25% triangular

Notes:

wall line count with 0.4 mm print head nozzle is 3 and with 300 micron resolution 4 on the top and bottom. The butt is sitting on the print bed.
Your printer should be able to handle 6.5" or 165 mm tall parts.

How to build it

You can use various braided cords for the center but make sure it has enough strength to handle the centrifugal force.
Feed the cord through the handle and tie a knot at the racquet handle butt to stop slipping through.
For the head part I used 4 warn and/or soft tennis balls I had at home. To create the ball holder part, you can get very creative. I had some very strong window blind material at home and made a tube with an overlocker, sewing machine is good too but with the overlocker it is simpler and faster.
You can also stuff the balls into a sock and tie it to the end of the cord, making sure that the overal length is no longer than 27" or 685 mm.
Some kind of net tube would also work if the netting is strong enough.
To finish the creation I rapped proper tennis over grip on it to simulate the racquet handle feel.

Weight Adjustment

You can adjust the weight by using up to 4 balls. I would not go higher than 4. If you want more weight, than you could cut a small hole on one of the tennis balls and squeeze some liquid nail adhesive through the hole. Let it dry for a while to allow the glue to skin and that way it will not come out of the ball. You can get liquid nail from your local hardware store for next to nothing. It is cheap in large tubes, more than 0.5 lb or 250 g, and dries flexible. It will not dry to be rock hard, hence it will not injure the user or someone else. Note: do not block the hole so the glue can set. If you filled one tennis ball with liquid nail and you still need more weight then repeat it on a second ball with the appropriate volume of liquid nail that will give you the desired weight.
If you want less balls, perhaps because you used a short socks as the ball head part, but the weight is not enough then you can do the above.

description.text:
Simple replacement case for USB sticks.

Designed for USB stick with a width of 14mm and a maximum depth of 35mm

My USB sticks were press-fit, but otherwise you could put in a drop of hotglue.

Types of plastic in the pictures:
Blue: Normal PLA
White: Glow in the dark PLA
Yellow: Heat sensitive PLA (the usb came out of my car and heated up as it was being used by the radio. base color is orange)

Monoprice Select Mini
